trial_identification.studytitle: Oral or rectal, diclofenac or paracetamol for the relief of perineal pain after childbirth: a randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial comparing pain scores for rectal Diclofenac with oral Diclofenac and oral or rectal Paracetamol in primiparous women after childbirth.

interventions.interventions: Control Group, Group 1: Rectal diclofenac 100mg every 12 hours for 48 hours, Group 2: Rectal paracetamol 1g every 6 hours for 48 hours, Group 3: Oral diclofenac 50mg every 8 hours for 48 hours, Group 4: Oral paracetamol 1g every 6 hours for 48 hours
interventions.comparator: 1. Rectal diclofenac; 100mg every 12 hours for 48 hours

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain scores utilising the Short-form McGill Pian Questionnaire
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 24hours, 48 hours and 6 weeks post commencement of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Satisfaction with medication utilising a Visual Analogue scale, 0= not satisfied at all to 10 = extremely satisfied
Recommendation of medication utilising a Visual Analogue scale, 0= no not at all to 10 = yes absolutely
Side effects: nausea, indigestion, vomiting, stomach pains, diarrhoea, constipation, difficulty passing urine - all participant reported with tick box
Additional analgesia for pain recorded on patient medication chart and participant reported with tick box
Use of ice packs participant reported with tick box
Length of Hospital stay as recorded in medical records.
Blood Pressure measured by clinician using a sphygmomanometer
Postnatal depression score using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Score
Maternal satisfaction with birth experience utilising a Visual Analogue scale, 0= not satisfied at all to 10 = extremely satisfied
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 24 hours, 48 hours and 6 weeks post birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Breastfeeding rates, participant reported with tick box for breastfeeding with help, breastfeeding without help or not breastfeeding
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 24 hours, 48 hours and 6 weeks post birth

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Primiparous women who have a second-degree tear or greater or an episiotomy after a vaginal birth.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Contraindications to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications History of gastrointestinal ulcer or bleeding Significant renal or liver impairment Preeclampsia and essential hypertension. Asthma Postpartum haemorrhage greater than 1000mL Medical disorders associated with a disturbed coagulation profile, in particular immune thrombocytopenic purpura, disseminated intravascular coagulation Women of non-English speaking background Women taking anticoagulants, Lithium, Digoxin, Chloramphenicol or diuretics

trial_design.concealment: Eligible primiparous women received written information about the trial from 36 weeks onwards. Women provided informed written consent prior to birth but were randomized only following birth and assessment of the perineum. Randomisation was to one of four groups. Medications were packaged by the clinical trial pharmacist and allocated a study number based on the randomisation schedule. Each treatment pack contained forty-eight hours of the designated analgesia that was not concealed. The randomised medication was commenced immediately following perineal repair.
trial_design.sequence: The randomisation schedule was prepared using a computer generated permutated randomisation block

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study provides evidence of the effectiveness of both the most commonly used analgesics (Diclofenac and Panadol), and the mode of administration (oral or rectal), in relieving perineal pain after childbirth. We hypothesised that: 1. Regular oral analgesia is equally as effective as rectal analgesia in relieving perineal pain after childbirth. 2. Diclofenac is more effective an analgesia than Panadol. 3. Women prefer oral analgesia to rectal analgesia.
